user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;
    int32                             return_code;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    if (pthread_cond_destroy(&(sem->cv)) != 0)
    {
        /* sem could be busy, i.e. some task is pending on it already.
         * that means it cannot be deleted at this time. */
        return_code = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Now that the CV is destroyed this sem is unusable,
         * so we must do our best to clean everything else.  Even if cleanup
         * does not fully work, returning anything other than OS_SUCCESS would
         * suggest to the caller that the sem is still usable which it is not.
         */
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

        /* destroy the associated mutex --
         * Note that this might fail if the mutex is locked,
         * but there is no sane way to recover from that (see above). */
        pthread_mutex_destroy(&(sem->id));
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemDelete_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_MAX_BIN_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t       id;
    pthread_cond_t        cv;
    volatile sig_atomic_t flush_request;
    volatile sig_atomic_t current_value;
} OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I reviewed all pointer uses in OS_BinSemDelete_Impl and the related definitions. The function parameter token is already const-qualified (const OS_object_token_t *token). The local pointer sem points into the global OS_impl_bin_sem_table and is used to call pthread_cond_destroy(&sem->cv) and pthread_mutex_destroy(&sem->id); these POSIX APIs require pointers to modifiable pthread_cond_t / pthread_mutex_t objects, so sem cannot be a pointer-to-const. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro ultimately yields &tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))], and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken accepts a const OS_object_token_t*; passing *token leads to &(*token) which is the original const pointer, so const-correctness is preserved for the index lookup. The global array OS_impl_bin_sem_table and the volatile fields in the record are inherently mutable in this context. Therefore there are no obvious places where a pointer should be changed to point to a const-qualified type; no fragments require investigation for Rule 8.13.
